												Panzer Corps is a turn-based strategy or ‘wargame’. Each scenario you are tasked with deploying your troops and taking a set number of objectives across the map. Units earn experience and can be upgraded during the deployment phase with any new equipment unlocked. This is done using prestige points that you acquire by completing objectives and are also used to reinforce units during battle when they lose strength. Prestige points are persistent throughout the campaign meaning spending all of your points in one battle may not be wise as you are effectively depleting your resources for the next engagement; although you do receive some at the beginning of each scenario, what you have carries over.The graphics of Panzer Corps are fairly basic although nice to look at with each type of unit distinguishable from each other. Sounds can also said to be somewhat basic as each unit type has a single sound that is played during movement and attack. This may sound repetitive however after 18 hours of playing Panzer Corps I can say this has yet to bother me. The interface is effective at doing the job and gives you access to all of the information you need without being intrusive.Panzer Corps strikes a great balance between depth and accessibility and offers a great entry point into wargames for the uninitiated. The gameplay is addictive and the visuals and audio serve the game well, while the multiplayer uses a play-by-email method so multiple games can be played at once over the course of a few or more days.Panzer Corps has quickly become one of my favourite games and I would happily recommend it to anyone.

												Easily my favorite war game on PC was the SSI classic Panzer General (1993).   PG went on to have 4-5 sequals and generally was a fan favorite for a decade.   Luckly for us Slitherine decided to dust off this classic with a bit newer graphics but the same old fun gameplay.   If you loved PG then stop reading this review buy the game and play.  If you are new to the series lets go over what makes it fun.  First unlike many other war games its very easy to pick up learn and enjoy.  Most gamers should be able to pick up most of what they need to learn in under 30 minutes of play.  Next for those of us who like detail but dislike horrible interfaces Panzer Corps has an easy to use interface that is nearly perfict.  Finally the depth of the historical missions are fun and exciting.  Eventually you will get attached to some of your brigades and be pitching a fit if one gets nailed in a bad spot.   Now for the bad....One area that really could use some help is music, its ok but after awhile you wish you could just turn it off.  Its not cheep but its not well done.  Also while they were faithfull to the old PG game they really didnt try to bring in something new that would wow the audience.  Perhaps a research element, perhaps better naval options, perhaps better ways to manage air cover who knows but they really didnt change any core gameplay.  Yes this isnt necessarly a bad thing PG was a darn good game but that was 20 years ago.  All in all the game is easily worth 50 without the DLC.  If you are a wargamer this is a must buy if there ever was one.  If you are on the fence or just havent played a war game before I would say there is no other game that could possibly be a better game to try.

												Panzer Corps can be qualified as a successor to the famous and rewarded Panzer General series. In this game you take command of the German forces in World War II, sometimes assisted by their allies and must complete various objectives such as destroying a target or more often conquer the map. Panzer Corps is a turned-based 2D game which means that you organise your movements, attacks or other strategic action before the enemy does his. The German campaign will lead you in several theaters of the war such as the invasion of France, the taking of Norwegian's Narvik city, the assistance of Italian troops in their invasion of Greece or the famous operation Barbarossa. The campaign offers a continuity in the various operations which means you will keep your units from a theater to another. That way you will quickly care for your troops as they gain experience, medals and war heroes and you will try to keep the best of your regiments alive. Loosing a battle does not mean the end of the campaign or that you will automatically have to start again but you will continue the fight with a scenario according to your defeat. Now let's see the highs and lows of the game :[/b]- Good replayability : with various difficulties and numerous strategies possible you will like to start again a scenario and try to win it a different way.- The difficulty levels : They really offer a different difficulty which will accomodate the different kinds of players from novice to the master generals/ - The map is not just there to be pretty: Like a proper wargame, terrains matter. You may not want to attack while crossing a river, forests take longer to cross and units will move differently depending on their transport system ( trucks, on foot,...Etc )- Graphisms : Some will say come on we are in the 2010s but I like the graphism. The interface is very good and clean which is not always the case in these games and the units are clean as well. Once you are accustomed you will recognize the unit by their looks easily. - The sounds : there are not many sounds but they are correct and not horrible. Repetitive but very correct. The same goes with the music, it's not an epic music but it's enjoyable You may quickly forget that there is music though.- Multiplayer-Tutorial ( some games forget about tutorials so it's a good point. I jumped right into the game but for novice players it is important ).- There are achievements will add some new objectives if you like that kind of things.- Very fast, the end turns are quick ( The End of All Wars ? )- There is a demo on the official website. Some people don't care but I find very important that games have a demo, only to see if it works on your computer. - Where are the objectives ? Only when you end you turn and that's a shame. It's either hidden very well and in that case it's a low point as well but I can't find a single button to see my objectives during my turn. What follows is neither a high nor a low point: The DLCs. They had several new campaign ( the base game with the German campaign and the multiplayer already offers a lotn enough to see if you like the game ) such as with the Afrika Corps, the allied or more focused scenarios such as the year 1940,...Etc I bought two of them and I am happy with them. DLCs don't take away anything from the base game they just had new campaigns for those who want more. Some may not like it but at least features were not taken from the base game to be sold after as DLCs like so many games do. So I highly recommand this, for old Panzer General and the like fans as well for novice in this genre. It's very intuitive and you will soon get into the game without headaches. During my first play, I find myself playing three hours in a row withou t noticing time passing. 8.5/10
